newsitem.title: GERMANY: Study shows high baking quality in German wheat.
newsitem.headline: Study shows high baking quality in German wheat.

text.p: Germany's 1996 wheat crop showed high baking qualities but weather damage caused wide regional variations, the state quality assessment centre for grain, potatoes and fats (BAGKF) said.
Millers were advised to be very selective in their buying, said BAGKF in a report. It had studied 2,500 samples.
But there was ample supply to meet the usual requirements of consumers in the domestic milling industry and of importers in Benelux countries, France, Britain and Italy.
Average wheat protein contents rose to 13.2 percent from 12.9 percent in 1995.
A range of other baking quality tests -- on the strength of flour, flour extraction rates, and Hagberg numbers -- also showed better results than last year.
Official data put the crop up by 6.2 percent to 18.94 million tonnes, from a 2.60 million hectare area (up 0.7 percent), and amid yield rises by 5.9 percent to 7.29 tph.
Bavaria harvested 3.18 million tonnes, followed by Lower Saxony's 2.67 million and North-Rhine Westphalia's 2.17 million, BAGKF said.
Yields were highest in Schleswig-Holstein (8.61 tph) and North-Rhine Westphalia (8.50 tph) compared with just 5.61 tph in Brandenburg state.
BAGKF said wheat with more than 14 percent protein and medium Hagberg falling numbers around 250 was especially suited for export as importers use it to blend it with local standard wheat.
The share of such wheat (mostly of so-called "A" and "E" grades) in the 1996 harvest rose by five percent to 28.8 percent of the total.

Crops in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Saxony-Anhalt, Brandenburg and Thuringia, all in former eastern Germany, had the highest proportion of top "E" grades within their overall result. -Vera Eckert, Hamburg newsroom, +49-40-41903275
